problem: The points $A(2,5), B(6,5), C(5,2)$ and $D(1,2)$ are the vertices of a parallelogram. If the parallelogram is translated down 2 units and right three units, what will be the coordinates of the final image of point $B$?
solution: When an image is translated to the right we just add the number of units it is being translated to the original $x$-coordinate. When an image is translated down we just subtract that number of units from the $y$-coordinate. In this case we'll subtract 2 from the $y$-coordinates and add 3 to the   $x$-coordinates. This will make point $B(6, 5)$ move to $B'(6 + 3, 5 - 2) = \boxed{(9, 3)}$.
model_solution:
Step 1: Identify the initial coordinates of point B.
The initial coordinates of point B are (6,5).
Step 2: Translate the coordinates of B down 2 units and right 3 units by applying the respective changes in the x and y-coordinates.
Step 3: Apply the translation to the coordinates of B, resulting in the new coordinates of B being (6+3, 5-2) = (9, 3).
Step 4: The new coordinates of B are (9, 3).
Step 5: The coordinates of the final image of point B are (9, 3).
Step 6: The final image of point B after translation is (9,3).
Step 7: The final image of point B after translation is (9,3).
Step 8: The coordinates of the final image of point B are (9, 3).
Step 4: The new coordinates of B are (9, 3).
